text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today I am 
remaking one of my most popular videos satay

and peanut sauce now satay is a street food it's 
everywhere on the streets of Thailand and it's

also really popular entire restaurants overseas 
and today is a new and improved recipe and super

excited about I'm doing mousse fa is pork and so 
that is that day and I'm choosing pork because

it's essentially the only kind of satay you can 
find in Thailand however it'll work really well

with chicken or beef so whatever you want let's 
get started I'm going to first make the marinade

and the satay marinade is just full of herbs and 
spices it's essentially good on anything coriander

seeds and cumin seeds which are both toasted you 
want to toast them in a dry saute pan just until

they start to turn brown a little bit to open up 
all that aroma activate all those flavor molecules

so once I've got it very very fine I'm going to 
add lemongrass and galangal I've got lemongrass

just finely chopped and galangal as well oh 
then my lemongrass and dangal is also quite

fine turmeric now I'm using powder turmeric 
but you can also use the fresh roots if you

want if you've got access to that it would be 
even better white pepper and some cinnamon and

clove which I find just add a little bit of 
a warm spice flavor and then a little added

sweetness about some brown sugar white sugar or 
palm sugar would work as well and some salt and

now all the liquid coconut milk keep things moist 
add some flavor this is what makes Thai satay so

unique a little bit of vinegar a little acidity 
helps sort of brighten up the flavor of the meat

it'll also help just tenderize it just slightly 
a little bit of water and now I'm adding quite a

lot of liquid because essentially this is half 
marinate half brine and that's pretty much the

marinade let's get to the meat for satay I like 
to use pork loin which works really well on the

grill it's lean but it's tender however when I 
cut it there's a little trick that I like to do

the pork loin always comes with this fat right 
here and I want to make sure that that fat gets

distributed evenly throughout the skewer so that 
you don't have one piece with just all the fat

because a little bit of fat in each skewer is 
actually nice and now I just pour the marinade

all over the pork the important thing here is that 
you make sure that there's no two pieces of pork

that are sticking together you want to really get 
in there and massage it and make sure they're all

separated so they all have equal access to this 
marinade and notice how much liquid there is in

this bowl that's what I'm going for I want to 
make sure there's enough liquid so that as it

sits it penetrates the meat and keep the meat 
juicy oh by the way when you're working with

turmeric be really careful it stains everything 
and it stains everything forever it's impossible

to get off if you've got tricks on how to get off 
turmeric stains on your cutting board and clothing

tell me if I don't know what that is so now I'm 
going to let that sit overnight but if you're in

a rush a couple hours two hours three hours it's 
just fine so we'll be right back while the pork

is marinating let's make the peanut sauce you may 
have heard me say before but even though peanut

sauce is associated with Thai cuisine the only 
time we actually eat peanut sauce is with pork

satay so here we go some ground peanuts I'm not 
using peanut butter because I actually want the

gritty texture that's part of the fun of this 
sauce so that's just peanuts that I ground up in

a food processor and my little trick I've also got 
some ground sesame seeds so toasted white sesame

seeds it's optional you can just use all peanuts 
but it's just something that I've discovered over

the years so it works really really well and I'm 
going to add a little bit of coconut milk and let

this reduce until thick now this is a very similar 
beginning as when I make coconut based curries

which is starting with reducing coconut milk 
and then I'm going to saute my curry paste in it

so once it's reduced by about half I'm going 
to add my curry paste and I'm using red curry

paste today but the satay sauce will also be 
delicious if you've got Panang curry paste or

muscleman curry paste and you just get slightly 
different flavors both Penang and must mint has

more of the dry spices the cumin and coriander and 
cinnamon things like that Oh spicy so any of you

can see this but you can see bubbling oil coming 
out around the edges of the curry paste that's the

coconut oil that's separating that's what I'm 
looking for okay so when that happens adding

the rest of my coconut milk and also a peanuts 
and the sesame oil give that a good stir get it

all mixed up and then I'm going to add some palm 
sugar because this will be sort of slightly salty

and sweet kind of sauce just going to add a little 
bit of fish sauce and again you'll have to taste

and adjust because every brand of curry paste is 
not equally salty and to balance that saltiness

and the sweetness and the richness some acidity 
tamarind juice you may need more or less depending

on the brand but this one I'm going to bring it 
to a simmer and let it reduce until thick and

keep stirring it so that it doesn't scorch on the 
bottom so the consistency is where I want it now

so I'm going to turn that off and if you notice 
there's a thin layer of red oil on top that is

totally fine and it's totally a characteristic 
of our satay peanut sauce that's just a coconut

oil with the color of the red curry paste infused 
into it so I'm going to do a final taste it does

need a little bit of sugar this will be good on 
anything even if you have this leftover you'd be

good as a vegetable dip tofu tofu with this port 
on top brilliant so here's the part that's been

marinating for a few hours but if you notice 
there's less liquid now in the bowl than there

was when it first went in and that's because of 
the liquid when in the heart you know the pork is

plump and juicy scaring these are just 6 inches 
long and that's because in Thailand the satay

skewers are pretty small like that they're snacks 
I always make sure that on every skewer there's a

fatty piece so remember the piece where I cut and 
there's a slice of fat attached to it I want to

make sure on every skewer there's at least one 
of those so here we are outside on the balcony

grilling I've got all my skewer ring done and 
what I'm going to do is I'm going to brush one

side of the skewers with the coconut and what 
this does is it will help moisten the skewers

you see them do this on the street and because the 
pork loin is clean and because we are drying it

cooking this I eat the grill the coconut milk will 
just help slow down moisture loss and keep things

nice and moist all righty and the heat doesn't 
have to be high for this is going to cook so

quickly this lowest medium is just fine and I am 
putting the skewers down coconut milk side down
so that I then brush the other side

there are two more things in order for us to have 
a complete Street food satay experience one is

toast satay is often served with just grilled 
white toast and the bread is grilled directly

on the grill that the pork is grilled on so I've 
got that and the other one is what we call at dad

at that is basically a quick pickle and I've 
got here some cucumber some shallots and some

spiritual ease you can just do red bell peppers 
or jalapenos you want spicy and then I've got

the pickling liquid and the pickling liquid is 
basically vinegar and sugar that's been cooked

down and then let it cool all the way before 
pouring on to it because what we're trying to do

is making sure that the cucumber and the shallots 
remain bright and fresh and crunchy so you don't

want to pour hot pickling liquid on it and so 
that's why I call it a quick pickle our lovely

lovely grilled satay on the plate and that's 
just like on the street let's see how it tastes

mmm the top of the skewer you just you 
were a piece of cucumber from the pickle

the pork is tender salty and the sauce is 
rich and sweet so that crunchy tart pickle

just works really well to balance it and what 
you do with this host is you basically just

dip it into the sauce as well so the next time 
you're going to fire up your grill remember the

satay this is so easy and it works well on 
chicken beef pork or even tofu so when you

give it a try let me know how it goes send me 
a photo on Facebook Twitter or Instagram the

recipe as always about Hal Thai kitchen calm and 
I will see you next time for your next delicious
you
